content.title: The Role of Public Sector In Sustainable Energy Finance
content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

This lesson discusses the critical role of public sector investment in supporting renewable energy projects in developing countries. It highlights how governments and public financial institutions can leverage resources to mitigate investment risks, attract private sector involvement, and support early-stage projects. Learners will also explore how public investments align with international climate goals and drive economic growth, job creation, and energy access in underserved regions. The lesson provides examples of how effective public sector interventions can unlock the financing needed to scale up renewable energy projects.

concepts.title: fiscal policies
concepts.body: Fiscal policies are government strategies regarding taxation and spending to influence a country's economy.

concepts.title: public investment management (pim)
concepts.body: Public Investment Management (PIM) refers to the processes and practices used by governments to plan, execute, and oversee investments in public projects and services, ensuring efficient use of resources and maximizing social and economic benefits.

concepts.title: regulatory support and policy frameworks
concepts.body: Regulatory support and policy frameworks are structured guidelines and rules established by governments or organizations to promote, manage, and enforce practices related to energy use, sustainability, and environmental protection.

content.title: Part 1: Should government investment in sustainable energy?

content.text: The transition to renewable energy systems requires significant investment across a wide range of activities, from infrastructure development to research and capacity building. While private sector participation is critical, the public sector often plays a foundational role by mobilizing and channeling financial resources where market mechanisms fall short. Public finance not only supports direct investments but also creates enabling environments that reduce risks and encourage private sector participation. In other words, public funds are critical in areas where the private sector perceives higher risks or lower returns, such as in early-stage technology development or markets with less established regulatory frameworks. At its core, public finance for renewable energy operates through a structured flow of resources. This flow begins with the sources of funding, which can be broadly categorized as international and national. International sources include multilateral and bilateral institutions such as the Green Climate Fund (GCF) and Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP), which focus on large-scale, cross-border, or high-risk projects. National sources, including governments, state-owned enterprises (SOEs), and local financial institutions, cater to the specific needs and priorities of domestic energy transitions. These funds are managed and distributed through intermediaries, including development banks, governments, and innovative platforms like carbon finance mechanisms. The intermediaries ensure that funds are directed toward priority areas, balancing short-term project needs with long-term policy objectives. The distribution is facilitated by a variety of financial instruments, ranging from direct subsidies and concessional loans to equity stakes and fiscal incentives like tax breaks or accelerated depreciation.

Ultimately, public finance supports the implementation of various policy categories, such as: Deployment policies that focus on direct investments in renewable energy infrastructure. Integration policies that address the technical and systemic challenges of incorporating renewables into existing energy systems. Enabling policies that promote capacity building, research, and development. Structural and just transition policies that aim to correct market failures and ensure equity in energy transitions. Research and Development by providing funding, incentives, and infrastructure to advance technological innovation. The diagram below provides a detailed representation of this flow, illustrating the interconnectedness of funding sources, intermediaries, financial instruments, and policy categories. It offers a comprehensive framework for understanding how public finance drives renewable energy transitions. Capacity building and technical assistance also plays important roles in working with the local financial system to create an enabling environment, develop financial strategies, and conduct market assessments. This includes collaboration with international climate funds to structure guarantees, subsidies, and concessional loans, as well as leveraging resources from IFIs and capital markets. Ensuring efficient resource allocation and effective implementation is key to maximizing impact.

Public sector investment in sustainable energy is driven by a confluence of environmental, economic, and social motivations. National public sector investment is driven by national and subnational development priorities, including social and gender considerations, political, economic development, environmental and biodiversity protection, financial stability, and governance. On the other hand, international public sector investment is primarily guided by the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and climate action objectives.
At the heart of these investments lies the urgent need to combat climate change through the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

Governments worldwide recognize that transitioning to clean energy sources such as solar, wind, and hydroelectric power is critical for achieving this goal. At the 2024 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP29) in Baku, Azerbaijan, developed nations committed to mobilize at least $300 billion annually by 2035 to assist developing countries in combating climate change. This agreement, known as the "New Collective Quantified Goal on Climate Finance‚Äù aims to support developing countries in transitioning to clean energy sources and enhancing resilience against climate-related disasters. Furthermore, sustainable energy investments can be seen as a means to enhance national energy security by allowing fossil fuel importers to reduce dependence on imports, which are subject to volatile prices and geopolitical tensions.
Economic motivations are equally compelling

Investing in sustainable energy infrastructure stimulates job creation in new and emerging sectors, fostering economic growth and diversification. Public investments also catalyze private sector participation, drawing in additional resources and expertise. Social motivations, including improving public health through reduced air pollution and increasing energy access in underserved communities, further underpin the public sector's commitment to sustainable energy.
Example
Public sector investments can have a profound impact on the growth of the renewable energy market.

By providing initial capital, facilitating research and development, and offering financial incentives such as tax credits and feed-in tariffs, the public sector reduces the risks associated with investing in new energy technologies. This, in turn, attracts private investment, driving down costs through economies of scale and technological advancements. The establishment of clear regulatory frameworks and policies by governments further stimulates market growth. Policies that mandate clean energy usage, coupled with investments in grid infrastructure to accommodate variable renewable energy sources, ensure a stable market for sustainable energy products and services. Additionally, public sector investments in education and workforce training prepare a skilled labor force to support the expanding clean energy sector.
The alignment of public sector investments with international climate goals and commitments is pivotal.

Agreements such as the Paris Agreement under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) set ambitious targets for reducing global greenhouse gas emissions. Public sector investments in sustainable energy are critical for countries to meet their nationally determined contributions (NDCs) to these international commitments. UNFCCC Agreements such as the Paris Agreement under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) set ambitious targets for reducing global greenhouse gas emissions, requiring countries to make significant public sector investments in sustainable energy to meet their nationally determined contributions (NDCs). These investments are shaped by national and subnational priorities, including social and gender considerations, economic development, environmental and biodiversity protection, financial stability, and governance. At the same time, aligning national investments with international public sector priorities‚Äîprimarily guided by the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and climate action objectives‚Äîenables countries to leverage international resources, such as grants and financial instruments, to overcome key barriers and accelerate progress toward global climate commitments. These investments not only contribute to global efforts to limit temperature rise but also signal a country's commitment to sustainable development and international cooperation. Moreover, international climate finance mechanisms, including the 300 billion Green Climate Fund Collective Quantified Goal (NCQG) and the Climate Investment Funds, support developing countries in their transition to sustainable energy systems. These mechanisms rely on public sector contributions from developed nations, highlighting the interconnectedness of global efforts to finance sustainable energy and achieve climate goals. UNFCCC
Government Spending on Energy Affordability

Governments have allocated USD 900 billion to short-term consumer affordability measures in response to the global energy crisis in early 2022, in addition to existing support programs and subsidies. Approximately 30% of the spending allocated for affordability has been announced within the late six months. Despite recommendations to focus on households and industries with the greatest need, only 25% of the affordability measures are directed towards low-income households and the most affected industries. The global fight against energy poverty highlights the need for equitable access to affordable energy, recognizing it as a fundamental public service. Governments play a crucial role in ensuring that all customer categories, especially the most vulnerable, have access to energy at fair prices through targeted social protection systems. This approach is particularly relevant for developing economies, where broad energy subsidies often fail to differentiate among consumers, inadvertently benefiting wealthier households rather than those in greatest need. Implementing more targeted subsidy mechanisms can enhance energy accessibility while promoting social equity and economic sustainability. Government should prioritize support to vulnerable groups and energy poor households as a short-term solution. In the longer term, support should be provided to improve energy efficiency and empowering consumers to tackle the root cause of energy poverty (such as e.g. low efficiency of residential buildings) The European Union provides two-thirds of government affordability support globally and has experienced some of the most significant rises in electricity and gas prices in 2022. Consumer support spending levels have risen in emerging and developing economies (EMDEs) due to governments compensating energy companies for operating losses incurred by maintaining stable prices during the energy crisis. EMDE governments have allocated more funds towards consumer affordability measures (USD 140 billion) than clean energy investment support (USD 90 billion) since 2020.

Emergency measures were crucial in protecting consumers from energy price increases but put significant strain on government finances due to a peak in fossil fuel subsidies in 2022. This may jeopardize certain countries' capacity to manage short-term relief while simultaneously tackling energy security and affordability by enhancing energy efficiency and investing in clean energy. Striking this balance is especially challenging in EMDEs because of existing financial pressures. The majority of spending on affordability and clean energy is concentrated in advanced economies, which account for 93% of total government clean energy investment support and 85% of consumer affordability support

content.title: Part 2: The Role of Public Sector Sustainable Energy Finance

content.text: Public Sector 'Above the Line' Financing

Public sector financing is essential for kick-starting sustainable energy projects, especially in regions where the initial investment cost is prohibitive, or the market is too risky for private investors. Public sector financing, supported by development finance institutions (DFIs) like DFID, DFC, JBIC, is vital for sustainable energy projects, especially where high costs or uncertainties deter private investment. By injecting funds directly into clean energy projects, governments can mitigate the risk, making these ventures more attractive to private investors. This is particularly important in developing countries, where the need for clean energy is urgent but the capacity to attract private capital is limited. IMF By providing direct funding, subsidies, and financial incentives, the public sector can lower the cost of clean energy technologies, making them more competitive with fossil fuels. Additionally, public investments can stimulate economic growth, create jobs in the clean energy sector, and lead to the development of local industries.
Regulatory Support and Policy Frameworks

The public sector also plays a pivotal role in creating conducive regulatory environments for sustainable energy investment. This includes setting up clear, consistent policies and regulatory frameworks that encourage investment in clean energy. Policies such as renewable auctions, feed-in tariffs, tax incentives, and renewable energy targets can significantly enhance the attractiveness of sustainable energy investments. By providing a stable and predictable investment landscape, governments can facilitate long-term planning and investment in clean energy projects. Institutional guidance plays a key role in ensuring the effective allocation and management of public funds for renewable energy. Establishing clear policies, regulatory frameworks, and institutions dedicated to renewable energy can enhance transparency, accountability, and efficiency in public investments. This includes setting up national energy agencies or funds specifically designed to finance renewable energy projects.
Facilitating the Ground for Collaboration

Collaboration mechanisms between the public and private sectors, such as public-private partnerships (PPPs) and concession models, can enhance the effectiveness of clean energy financing. Public-private partnerships can mobilize additional resources for sustainable energy projects. By sharing the financial burden and risks associated with large-scale renewable energy projects, governments can attract private sector investment, thus expanding their fiscal capacity without compromising their financial stability. In Chapter 5, PPPs will be explained in more details. These mechanisms allow for sharing the risks and benefits of clean energy projects, making them more attractive to private investors. International cooperation, including support from multilateral development banks and international financial institutions, is also essential in providing the necessary capital and expertise. Moreover, governments can play a crucial role in partnering with international cooperation and development finance institutions to support sustainable energy financing, especially in low- and middle-income countries. Multilateral development banks and international financial institutions can provide both financial and technical assistance to enhance and assess the sustainability impact of projects and help countries transition to sustainable energy systems. This support is vital for countries that lack the financial resources or expertise to develop and implement sustainable energy projects on their own. Energy Service Companies (ESCOs) and Energy Performance Contracts (EPCs) also play a crucial role in mobilizing investments in renewable energy and energy efficiency. ESCOs provide comprehensive energy solutions, including audits, retrofits, and performance-based financing, allowing businesses and public institutions to reduce energy costs without upfront capital. EPCs offer a financial model where project costs are repaid through energy savings, reducing investment risks for clients. By leveraging ESCOs and EPCs, governments and businesses can accelerate the transition to cleaner, more sustainable energy systems.
Improving Public Expenditure Management

Enhancing the efficiency and efficacy of public expenditure management is another avenue through which governments can create fiscal space. By prioritizing spending, eliminating wasteful expenditures, and improving the efficiency of public services, governments can reallocate resources toward sustainable energy and climate resilience projects. Governments play a key role in improving project bankability, managing risks and creating an environment for investments to flourish. Therefore, it is crucial for countries to establish sound Public Investment Management (PIM) policies and procedures. Effective PIM ensures that public investments, particularly in capital-intensive sectors like renewable energy, are efficiently planned, executed, and monitored. PIM plays a vital role in prioritizing investments based on strategic importance and socio-economic benefits, thus ensuring that limited public funds are directed towards high-impact sustainable development and energy transition projects. Moreover, PIM frameworks incorporate risk assessment and management at the project planning stage, enabling governments to identify potential risks early and design mitigation strategies. This reduces the likelihood of project delays, cost overruns, and failures.

In addition, robust PIM frameworks help in identifying, preparing, and implementing investment projects that deliver value for money and align with national development goals. Countries can enhance investor interest and confidence by adopting long-term, ambitious clean energy strategies, including net zero commitments, as well as leveling the playing field through phasing out fossil-fuel consumption subsidies. Such plans are most effective when backed by clear and stable policies for accelerating the uptake of renewables and low-carbon fuels, improving energy efficiency, and enhancing regulatory frameworks for grid infrastructure and distributed solutions to support system integration and access goals. Coupling these efforts with targeted public finance and remuneration mechanisms that foster competition, such as auctions, helps to stimulate investor appetite.
Enhancing Fiscal Space

Enhancing fiscal space is a critical strategy for governments, especially in the context of financing sustainable energy projects. Fiscal space refers to the financial capacity of a government to provide additional budgetary resources for public spending without jeopardizing its financial stability and sustainability. In other words, it is the use of government spending and taxation to influence the economy. Governments typically use fiscal policy to promote strong and sustainable growth and reduce poverty. The role and objectives of fiscal policy gained prominence during the recent global economic crisis when governments stepped in to support financial systems, jump-start growth, create economic stimulus, and mitigate the impact of the crisis on vulnerable groups. Expanding this space is vital for supporting significant investments in clean energy and sustainability initiatives, which are essential for combating climate change and promoting economic development. For instance, implementing or reforming tax systems to increase government revenue is a fundamental approach. This can include introducing or increasing taxes on carbon emissions making the emission more costly, luxury goods, or on wealth, which not only generate revenue but can also encourage more environmentally and socially responsible behaviors.

Similarly, redirecting subsidies from fossil fuels to clean energy sources can significantly enhance fiscal space. Fossil fuel subsidies are often substantial, draining considerable resources that could instead support sustainable energy development. The IMF estimated that globally, fossil fuel subsidies were $7 trillion in 2022, or 7.1 percent of GDP. Phasing out these subsidies, while politically challenging, can free up significant funds for investment in sustainable energy projects and energy efficiency improvements. Reforming fossil fuel subsidies, perhaps by limiting them to households that lack the ability to pay for needed minimum energy services, is critical for redirecting financial flows toward clean energy. Subsidies for fossil fuels often dwarf investments in sustainable energy and perpetuate dependence on carbon-intensive energy usage. Phasing out these subsidies, while protecting vulnerable populations through targeted support, can free up substantial resources for investment in clean energy infrastructure and services.
Accessing International Public Finance

The public sector plays a pivotal role in enabling access to international finance for renewable energy projects, particularly in developing countries. Advancements such as blended finance mechanisms, sovereign green bonds, and climate-specific funds like the Green Climate Fund (GCF) and the EU Global Gateway, which leverages the EU budget alongside various financial instruments, including those from European multilateral and bilateral development banks, have opened new pathways for funding. Governments can leverage these opportunities by establishing robust financial architectures, aligning national policies with global climate goals, and enhancing transparency to attract foreign investments. At COP29, held in Baku, Azerbaijan, developed nations committed to mobilizing $300 billion annually by 2035 through the New Collective Quantified Goal (NCQG) on climate finance to support climate initiatives in developing countries, tripling the previous $100 billion target. This commitment aims to accelerate the transition to low-carbon economies and enhance resilience against climate change impacts. The World Bank Group has pledged to increase its climate finance allocation from 35% to 45% of total lending for fiscal year 2025, with a focus on both mitigation and adaptation efforts. Additionally, the World Bank has launched a $2 billion initiative to enhance energy security by scaling up renewable energy in emerging economies within Europe and Central Asia. These developments underscore the critical role of the public sector in mobilizing and directing international financial resources toward sustainable energy transitions.
Risk mitigation

Risk mitigation is a crucial function of the public sector in promoting sustainable energy investments, particularly in overcoming financial barriers that deter private sector participation. Renewable energy projects often face significant challenges, including high upfront costs, long payback periods, and uncertain returns, which can make them less attractive to private investors. To address these issues, the public sector can employ a range of financial instruments and mechanisms to reduce perceived risks and create an enabling environment for investment. For example, loan guarantees can offer assurances to lenders by committing the public sector to cover a portion of the loan in case of borrower default, thereby reducing the cost of capital for project developers. Similarly, insurance products, such as political risk insurance, protect investors from risks like policy changes, currency instability, or project delays, providing a more stable and predictable investment landscape. Another effective mechanism is first-loss protection, where the public sector agrees to absorb initial losses in a project, thus boosting investor confidence and attracting capital from risk-averse entities. Stay tuned for deeper insights and expanded discussions on this risk mitigation strategies in the chapter 3.

content.title: Case Study: The Noor Ouarzazate Solar Complex Morroco

content.text: The Noor Ouarzazate Solar Complex in Morocco is a pioneering model in renewable energy, leveraging blended finance and international funding. Initiated by the Moroccan Agency for Solar Energy (MASEN) in 2010, the project uses an integrated approach, including site identification, feasibility studies, and infrastructure construction. The Noor Ouarzazate Solar Complex in Morocco is a pioneering model in renewable energy, leveraging blended finance and international funding. Initiated by the Moroccan Agency for Solar Energy (MASEN) in 2010, the project uses an integrated approach, including site identification, feasibility studies, and infrastructure construction. MASEN provides substantial financial support through equity, debt capital, and long-term financing from international and domestic markets. Success is driven by innovative mechanisms like PPAs and government guarantees, which mitigate investor risks and ensure financial sustainability. This analysis examines the blend of private investment, government funding, and international support, focusing on MASEN's role and financing strategies. The project significantly impacts Morocco's energy transformation by addressing rising demand, enhancing security, and reducing emissions. Morocco's commitment to 52% renewable energy by 2030, highlighted at COP 21, underscores the project's success and implications for future initiatives. The Noor Solar Complex total installed capacity reaches 580 MW and an annual electricity production 618 GWh. The Noor complex aims to increase the share of renewable energy sources to 52% by 2030.

The Noor II and III Concentrated Solar Power (CSP) Plants in Ouarzazate utilize a multilateral debt financing model, involving significant collaboration between various international development finance institutions and bilateral agencies. Public-Private Partnership (PPP): The projects are implemented through a PPP model, where private sector sponsors are responsible for engineering, financing, procurement, construction, ownership, operation, and maintenance of the plants. This approach leverages private sector efficiency and expertise while ensuring public sector oversight and support. Multilateral and Bilateral Loans: A consortium of international financial institutions, including the African Development Bank (AfDB), European Investment Bank (EIB), World Bank‚Äôs International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), French Development Agency (AFD), and the Clean Technology Fund (CTF), among others, provided debt financing. This diversified funding base helps distribute financial risks and ensures the availability of adequate capital. On-Lending Structure: The financing is channeled through MASEN, which acts as an intermediary. MASEN receives loans from the multilateral development banks and then lends the funds to the project companies responsible for the construction and operation of the plants. This structure allows for better management and oversight of the funds.

Morocco's renewable energy strategy involves a combination of long-term low-interest loans, blended finance, risk mitigation instruments, equity contributions, and a phased approach. Development finance institutions provide loans, while concessional loans and grants from the European Commission reduce capital costs. The Ouarzazate solar power plant's first phase closed in June 2013, with the second phase in May 2015. The AfDB Group solely funded solely, phase one, costing ‚Ç¨500 million. The second phase of the Noor complex involved a $2 billion investment, with 80% loan and 20% equity. Risk mitigation instruments, including guarantees and viability gap funding, protected against financial risks. Equity contributions came from ACWA Power, Sener Ingener√≠a y Sistemas, and the debt facility was entirely provided by Masen with funds secured from the AfDB, the Agence Fran√ßaise de D√©veloppement, the Clean Technology Fund, the European Commission, the European Investment Bank, Kreditanstalt f√ºr Wiederaufbau and the World Bank. The phased approach releases funds as milestones are met, ensuring continuous support. The Noor II and III projects demonstrated the feasibility of deploying technologies for a sustainable energy transition while ensuring grid reliability. Public subsidies and risk mitigation instruments made CSP technology competitive with conventional energy sources in the Moroccan context. Collaborative partnerships between government entities, private developers, and international financiers were crucial for smooth implementation.

The project's success highlights the essential role of government support, public-private partnerships, concessional financing, and strategic technology selection in advancing large-scale renewable energy projects. These lessons underscore the importance of political will, innovative financing, and careful technology assessment in driving renewable energy adoption. The Noor Ouarzazate Solar Complex in Morocco has demonstrated the importance of government support, public-private partnerships, concessional financing, and strategic technology selection in advancing large-scale renewable energy projects. The project's early success demonstrates the replicability of Morocco's solar initiative for global renewable energy development. Key elements include dedicated agencies like MASEN, public-private partnerships, innovative financing mechanisms, and strategic technology selection. These strategies promote scalability and sustainability, adaptable to local conditions and enhanced by capacity building and knowledge transfer. The project exemplifies sustainability by reducing carbon emissions, creating jobs, and fostering economic growth. Future directions include expanding capacity and incorporating solar PV. This said, all new sustainability energy technologies can take many years to prove their ultimate performance in deployment. Therefore, technology selection and financing must be viewed as a dynamic process that requires constant review and adjustment.

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Governments play a pivotal role in kick-starting sustainable energy projects by providing funding, subsidies, and risk mitigation measures. These investments reduce uncertainties, attract private sector participation, and support the development of clean energy infrastructure and technologies.

Strong commitment from governments worldwide is critical to implementing ambitious policies, fostering international collaboration, and mobilizing resources needed to scale renewable energy and achieve global climate and energy goals.

Clear regulatory policies, phasing out fossil fuel subsidies, and creating fiscal space through targeted taxation and financial incentives are necessary to align national energy goals with global climate commitments, fostering an equitable and sustainable energy transition.
